content.question: A student is given the task of making a calibration curve for <math alttext="C o C l 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CoCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> for use in a spectrophotometry experiment. The student pours a sample of <math alttext="C o C l 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CoCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> of known concentration into a cuvette with a <math alttext="1.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"> <mn>1.0</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi>cm</mi> </math> path length and tries to measure the absorbance at <math alttext="500 nanometers" overflow="scroll"> <mn>500</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi>nm</mi> </math>, which is the wavelength of maximum absorbance. However, the absorbance is too high to give an accurate reading. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for the student?

choices.label: Switching to using a cuvette with a <math alttext="1.5 centimeters" overflow="scroll"> <mn>1.5</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi>cm</mi> </math> path length
Repeating the experiment after warming the solution to <math alttext="40 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn><mo>Â°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>
Diluting a measured volume of the solution to a new known volume using distilled water
Pouring some solution out of the cuvette

content.answer: Diluting a measured volume of the solution to a new known volume using distilled water
